Summary: TO for 12/4. Only limited patchy cover remains. Low hazard.
SnowDistribution: Diminishing snowpack, very limited patchy cover remains.  Cloudy on the tops with some bright spells.  Winds approx 50 - 60 mph
Comment: Only very patchy snow cover remains. Largest areas around on inland hills with coastal hills mainly snow free.
WeatherInfluences: Mild with Gale force South-Westerly winds. Scattered showers will be rain at all levels.
SnowStability: Areas of moist but stable snow will remain on mostly North to East aspects above 800m, largely confined to inland mountains with coastal hills and peaks mostly snow free. The avalanche hazard will be Low
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A mild dry day with Gale Force South-Westerly winds. The freezing level is above the summits.
ObservedSnowStability: The remaining patchy snow cover continues to thaw and diminish. Stablility is good in all locations. Largest areas remain on North to East aspects above 800 metres on the more inland hills, coastal hills largely snow free. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: GC for 12/4 Wet snowpack, localised wet snow instabilities mainly on N to E aspects above 900m. Remaining cornices unstable. Haz Low
SnowDistribution: No snow below 850 metres. Moist but generally stable snowpack. Cloud base was around 750 metres. Visibility was reasonable ok.
Comment: Unsettled conditions for Friday and Saturday morning some summits snow forecast for Saturday afternoon.
WeatherInfluences: Mild conditions with freezing levels well above the highest summits. Strong, South-Westerly winds will bring heavy rain through most of this next period.
SnowStability: The snowpack will diminish further in the mild and wet conditions. Stability will remain generally good on all but the steepest slopes where some localised surface wet snow instabilities may exist. Areas mostly affected will be on North to Easterly aspects above 900 metres, particularly gully exits and steep coire headwalls. Any remaining cornices will be prone to collapse.  The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: It was dry with some sunny spells, summit temperatures were around plus four degrees celsius and the winds were fresh South-Westerly.
ObservedSnowStability: The snowpack is moist at all elevations and has diminished  further in the current mild conditions. However, stability remains generally good in most locations. Greatest snow amounts are present on North to Easterly aspects above 900 metres.  The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: NC 12.04 Generally good stability. Surface wet snow instabilities on steep N-E-S aspects above 1000m. Cornices weak. Low Hazard.
SnowDistribution: Wet snowpack. Good visibility, high cloud building later in the day. Winds approx 40-50 mph decreasing slightly in the afternoon.
Comment: Continuing hazard from rockfall in the thaw conditions. Looking colder into the weekend.
WeatherInfluences: The freezing level will remain above the summits throughout the forecast period. Storm force South-Westerly winds will ease only slightly for a time during the day becoming Gale force. Mostly dry during the day with drizzle overnight and then again later in the afternoon.
SnowStability: The snowpack will continue to thaw at all altitudes and stability will be generally good; however, shallow wet snow instabilities will be present mainly on steep North through East to South aspects above 1000 metres. Areas most affected will be coire rims, gully tops and crag aprons. Remaining cornices will be prone to collapse. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: The freezing level remained above the summits. Storm force West-South-Westerly winds decreased through the day to become strong. A sunny day with high cloud in the afternoon.
ObservedSnowStability: The snowpack is thawing at all levels.  After a period of instability overnight the snowpack started to slowly consolidate. Surface wet snow instabilities were observed on multiple aspects.  The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: LO for 12/4/24. The snowpack will remain well bonded and stable. Remaining cornices will be prone to collapse. Low hazard.
SnowDistribution: Wet snowpack. Cloudy on the tops with some bright spells. Winds 30 - 40 mph, progress difficult and tiring.
Comment: Best snow cover in North to East facing corries above 900 metres.
WeatherInfluences: Rain showers throughout the period with gale force South-Westerly winds. The freezing level will be above the summits.
SnowStability: The snowpack will remain well bonded and stability will be good. Remaining cornices will be prone to collapse. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: It was a dry day with gale force South-Westerly winds. The freezing level was above the summits.
ObservedSnowStability: The snowpack is well bonded and stable in all locations. Remaining cornices are prone to collapse. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: SC 12.4.24 Thawing snowpack. Wet snow instabilities, cornice collapse a hazard. Snow mainly N to E corries. Avalanche Hazard Low.
SnowDistribution: Wet snow throughout. Good visibility.   Winds approx 40 - 50 mph making progress very difficult and strenuous.
Comment: Windy conditions forecast. Falling rock and snow a hazard in corries.
WeatherInfluences: The freezing level will remain well above the summits with light rain in the afternoon. Winds will be strong, mainly South-Westerly during the day.
SnowStability: The remaining snow will continue to thaw at all levels but remain generally well bonded. Wet snow instabilities will still be possible around steep terrain with collapsing cornice remnants also a hazard. Greatest amounts will be encountered above 950 metres, on West through North to East facing corries and on the higher mountains of the main Cairngorm plateau area.  The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A bright and dry day with the freezing level above the summits. Winds were initially very strong from the West but starting to ease later.
ObservedSnowStability: There has been a significant loss of snow coverage. The remaining snow is soft but generally well bonded. Greatest amounts are present above 900 metres on West through  North to East facing aspects.  The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: CM for 12.4: Potential for rock, ice fall and minor full depth avalanches from steep crags. Remaining cornices will weaken. Low  Haz
SnowDistribution: Wet snow throughout.  Good visibility.  Winds approx 40 - 50 mph making progress very difficult and strenuous.
Comment: Some potential for falling rocks, ice, cornices and minor full depth avalanches during the sustained thaw.
WeatherInfluences: Very mild with moderate rainfall throughout the period. Strong South-West winds.
SnowStability: The patchy and moist snowpack will continue to diminish but remain well stabilised at all altitudes and in most locations. Some residual potential for cornice collapse above selected very steep East aspects and minor full depth avalanches from the Post Face of Coire Ardair. Rock and ice fall will be persistent objective dangers in the vicinity of steep crags.  The avalanche hazard will be Low
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Heavy overnight rainfall then dry. Mild, warm and sunny during the day. Strong South-West winds.
ObservedSnowStability: Very patchy snow cover limited to locations above 800m. The snowpack is moist and thawing at all altitudes but is generally well stabilised. Minor full depth avalanche activity observed this morning from the Post Face of Coire Ardair. Some cornices remain intact over a few steeper East aspects.  The avalanche hazard is Low.
